sub_topic: Determining the empirical and molecular formulas of inorganic compounds
message_1: If a sample of a white powder contains 23.1% sodium, 14.3% sulfur and 62.6% oxygen by mass, what is the empirical formula of the compound?
message_2:
To find the empirical formula of the compound, we need to determine the mole ratio of sodium (Na), sulfur (S), and oxygen (O) in the compound. We can do this by converting the mass percentages to moles.

Assume we have a 100 g sample of the compound. This means we have:
23.1 g of sodium (Na)
14.3 g of sulfur (S)
62.6 g of oxygen (O)

Now, we need to convert these masses to moles using the molar masses of each element:
Molar mass of Na = 22.99 g/mol
Molar mass of S = 32.07 g/mol
Molar mass of O = 16.00 g/mol

Moles of Na = 23.1 g / 22.99 g/mol = 1.005 moles
Moles of S = 14.3 g / 32.07 g/mol = 0.446 moles
Moles of O = 62.6 g / 16.00 g/mol = 3.913 moles

Now, we need to find the mole ratio by dividing each value by the smallest number of moles:
Mole ratio of Na = 1.005 / 0.446 = 2.25
Mole ratio of S = 0.446 / 0.446 = 1
Mole ratio of O = 3.913 / 0.446 = 8.76

Since these ratios are not whole numbers, we can round them to the nearest whole number to get the empirical formula:
Na_2SO_8

So, the empirical formula of the compound is Na2SO8.
